titleStmt.title: An Elegy on \underdotted·Demar·add·Damer\, the Jrish Miser

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Know all men by these presents, Death the Tamer
By mortgage hath secured the corps of \underdotted·Demar·add·Damer\.
Nor can four Hundred Thousand Sterling pound
Redeem him from his prison under Ground
His Heirs might well, of \add·all\ his wealth possest
Bestow to bury him an Jron Chest.
Pluto the God of wealth will Ioy to know
His faithfull Steward, in the shades below
He walked the streets and wore a Thread·bare Cloak
He dined and supped at charge of other folk
And by his looks had he held out his palms
He might be thought an object fitt for Alms
So, to yẹ poor if he refus'd his pelf
He us'd 'em full as kindly as himself.
Where'ere he went he never saw his Betters
Lords Knights and 'Squires were all his humble Debtors
And under hand & Seal the Jrish Nation
Were forced to own to him their Obligation
He that could once have half a Kingdom bought
In half a Minute is not worth a Groat;
His Coffers from yẹ Coffin could not save
Nor all his Jn'terst keep him from the Grave.
A Golden monument would not be right
Because we wish the Earth upon him light,
Oh London Tavern! thou hast lost a Friend,
Tho' in thy walls he ne're did Farthing spend:
He touch'd the pence, when others touch'd yẹ Pott.
The hand that sign'd ye mortgage paid the Shott.
Old as he was, no vulgar known Disease
On him could ever boast a power to seize
But as his Gold he weigh'd, grim death in spight
Cast in his dart, and made three moydores light;
And as he saw his darling Money fail,
Blew his last breath to sink the lighter \blotting\Scale.
He who so long was current, 'twould be strange
If he should now be cry'd down, since his change.
The Sexton shall green sods on thee bestow
Alas the Sexton is thy Banker now──
A Dismall Banker must that banker be
Who gives no Bills, but of Mortality──────────
The Epitaph for \underdotted·Demar·add·Damer\_Beneath this verdant Hillock lies
\underdotted·Demar·add·Damer\ the Wealty and ye Wise.

His Heirs, that he might safely rest,
Have put his Carcass in a Chest.
The very Chest in which they say,
His other self, his Money, lay.
And if his Heirs continue kind
To that dear self he left behind,
I dare believe, that four in five
Will think his better Self alive
